summary: The Direccion General de Inteligencia (DGI) was the Cuban intelligence agency. The documents reveal the DGI's activities, structure, and intelligence-gathering priorities, particularly in the Dominican Republic and Haiti, focusing on monitoring leftist forces, counterrevolutionary organizations, and CIA activities. The DGI was involved in training individuals in guerilla warfare and had representatives in various countries. The documents also mention Cuban communications intercepted between 1962 and 1964, providing insights into Cuban agent activities and reactions to the JFK assassination. Former DGI officers defected and provided information to the CIA. The CIA was interested in the DGI's operations and personnel, including those stationed at the Cuban UN Mission in New York. The documents also show the CIA's efforts to identify individuals connected to the DGI and KGB in Mexico City in 1963.
significance: While some documents mention intercepted Cuban communications and reactions to the JFK assassination, there is no direct evidence presented in these documents that the DGI was involved in the JFK assassination. One document mentions a former DGI officer who defected in 1964 and provided information indicating that the Cuban government was not involved in the Kennedy assassination.
